entry.key:
@<file_name>
Do you understand what I'm trying to achieve with these two files?
About the errors, what would be the difference between an Application error and a Domain error?
Ah I see, we have to throw in the abstract class, we can't make it return a Result?
Check the files because there are a lot of TS errors
Check the files because there are a lot of TS errors:

For the following code: ``` } return Result.ok(instance); } ``` We have the error: TypeScript-Go: Type 'Ok<T>' is not assignable to type 'Result<T, ZodError<unknown>>'. Type 'Result$1<T, never>' is not assignable to type 'Error<ZodError<unknown>>'. Type 'T' is not assignable to type 'never'. Type 'Entity' is not assignable to type 'never'. Please fix this. If needed, you can use the get_errors tool on this file.
I see, so to have a purist approach, I would only need to update my modules, not my TypeScript files?

I understand. So the fact that my TodoApplicationModule is importing the TodoInfrastructureModule is not a breach? This is understandable since it's a technical detail (NestJS), right? As long as the UseCase or Entities do not import infrastructure files directly?

I would like to avoid having a `props` property.
Ideally, I'd like every property to be public, even the ones inherited from Entity

I would like your help on my abstract class Entity. The goal is to be able to represent an entity by extending it. I want an entity to be automatically validated when instantiated without specifying it in the implementation class (TodoEntity here for example). I tried something as you can see but it seems fishy. Can you propose another solution?
Is there a way to define the zod schema and rely on it so that the class knows what are its properties?
It seems as error-prone as my approach. You still need to call Entity.createAndValidate. I would like the validation to happen during the instantiation of the TodoEntity. Do you think it's possible?

Taking this LinkedIn post (in French), is it true that Infrastructure should depends on Domain and not the other way around?
Is my app's infra depending on domain or the other way around? If yes, how can I fix this?

Taking this LinkedIn post (in French), is it true that Infrastructure should depends on Domain and not the other way around?
Is my app's infra depending on domain or the other way around? If yes, how can I fix this?
" Un dev fait de la "Clean Architecture". Toutes ses classes dépendent de tout.
La Clean Architecture est devenue un buzzword.
Tout le monde prétend en faire.
Presque personne ne la fait vraiment.
Cette semaine, je review un projet "Clean Architecture".
Organisation impeccable : → domain/ → application/ → infrastructure/
Le problème ?
Domain qui importe l'infra. Use cases qui appellent la BDD directement. Controllers couplés à tout (changement = casse tout). Impossible de tester sans tout monter.
Ce n'est pas de la Clean Architecture.
C'est juste une organisation de dossiers.
La Clean Architecture, ce n'est pas une question de structure de fichiers.
C'est une question de dépendances.
Les 3 règles non négociables :
→ Domain = zéro dépendance externe → Infrastructure dépend du domain (pas l'inverse) → Changer de framework sans toucher le métier
Les vrais signaux :
→ Tu peux remplacer PostgreSQL par MongoDB sans toucher le domain → Tu peux tester ton métier sans base de données → Tes entités ne connaissent ni Spring, ni Hibernate, ni Express
Si tu ne peux pas faire ça, tu n'es pas en Clean Architecture.
Ce que ça coûte vraiment :
→ Changement de BDD = 3 mois de refonte → Migration framework = réécriture complète → Tests impossibles sans infra → Dette technique qui explose à chaque évolution
Ce que j'observe chez 90% des projets "Clean Architecture" :
Domain couplé à l'infra. Use cases qui font du SQL direct. Impossible de tester unitairement. Changement de BDD = tout recommencer.
La Clean Architecture ne se résume pas à copier une structure de dossiers depuis un tuto YouTube.
C'est comprendre et respecter le principe d'inversion de dépendance.
Le test ultime :
Peux-tu tester ton domain sans aucune dépendance externe ?
Si la réponse est non, tu ne fais pas de Clean Architecture.
Tu as les dossiers. Pas l'architecture.
Votre "Clean Architecture" tient sans sa base de données ? "

The current approach is not working. I'll try to explain what I want and you can tell me if it's possible. If yes, you'll do it.
I want an abstract class Entity that will have some properties common to every class inhereting this class (childs).
I want their constructor to be private (or protected), I should not be able to instantiate an Entity using `new`, only static factory functions.
I want each child to define its own zod schema.
I want the Entity class to have a private method `validate` that will be called every time a new instance is created (so maybe in the constructor ?) but the child should not be really aware of it, I should not have to think about calling `validate` in each child, only to define the Zod schema that will be used to validate.
Altough, each factory method will need to return a Result since the validation can fail.
With the current code, can you fix `toDomainFromModel`?
With the current implementation, can you fix the toDomainFromModel method?
fix the edge case in calculate_average (it's a temp file)
